Here's UBS this morning on the data out of China:

11:12 am
JP11:13am

Growth momentum weakened, while property activity stayed resilient

After its strong rebound in March, China’s growth momentum in April slowed more than expected. Weakness in exports, retail sales and corporate CAPEX weighed on industrial production. Some one-off factors should have played a role, including the shock from the VAT cut on industrial production, difference in holiday dates on retail sales, and high base effect on exports. That said, the growth momentum seems still weak even after controlling for the above distortive factors. On the other hand, property activity stayed robust with slightly slower sales and new starts and strong investment, which is consistent with the sentiment improvement shown in our latest China Housing Survey.

JP11:13am

Trade war escalated; more policy easing to come

US-China trade war has escalated notably in the past 2 weeks. Our baseline scenario still sees a trade deal possible in late 2019 after much longer negotiations, and no further escalation from the current stage. However, the risk of a full-on trade war has increased materially. Given the weakness in April activity and recent trade war escalation, we think the government is likely to re-shift its macro policy stance to more of an easing bias again. Future policy support may include: more liquidity offering (including 100 bps of additional RRR cuts), lower market interest rates (but no benchmark rate cuts), rolling out of supportive measures for consumption, more support to the private sector, faster infrastructure spending, and less hawkish policy rhetoric on property.

JP11:13am

Revise down our GDP and CNY forecasts; expect Q2 growth to slow

We have downgraded our baseline forecast for GDP growth to 6.2% for 2019 and USDCNY to 7 at end-2019 (see forecast revision). We see Q2 GDP growth likely slowing to 6.2% from 6.4% in Q1. Trade war escalation will bring additional damage to China’s GDP growth, and more policy stimulus could offset part of such drag. The RMB will face more downward pressure, but the PBC should continue to manage the exchange rate and market expectations tightly. In the scenario of a full-on trade war (if one breaks out in 1-2 months), China’s GDP growth may fall below 6% in 2019 even with stronger stimulus, while CNY may weaken to 7.2.

red tvr tried that...
JP11:24am

Q1 has been seasonally soft as expected with c.15% of expected full year volumes against costs at stable annual run rate. Management is not changing full year guidance which should assist market confidence. However, whilst there are clear reasons for H2 weighting (normal seasonality, significant specials along with DBS Volante and Vantage AMR launches), the extent suggests further waypoints may be needed before a catalyst for the shares is reached.

JP11:26am

Volumes. Wholesale units 1,057 up from 963 +10% with core models 1,025 up from 915 +12%. Retail sales up 39% with company reporting dealer stocking returning to more normal levels. ASP on core models £149k from £160k due to mix, primarily due to Vantage launched in H2 2018, overall ASP £160k v £177k. Regionally APAC +30%, Americas +20%, Europe -4% and UK -9%.
● Financials. Gross margin 42.1% from 44.4% due to mix with more Vantage and fewer specials leaving gross profit flat at £83m. Operating costs increased in-line with the development plan; SG&A £53.9m from £38.5m +40% and D&A £30.5m from £21.7m +41%. SG&A similar to H2 2018 run rate of £57m a quarter reflecting increased marketing spend on new models (Vantage/DBS) and investment for the DBX. D&A increase reflects full run rate of new models and is in-line with the guidance of £140m for the year. This left an operating loss of £2.2m in the period against £22m profit the previous year. Note IFRS16 positive £3m and £5m currency tailwind. Post financing loss of £16.3m.

hornblower any grey from the Berenberg note on Metro?
11:26 am
JP11:26am

● Cash flow and balance sheet. The receivables which increased in light of the Q4 strength and delivery delays has largely unwound but inventory is higher reflecting normal seasonal patterns and to support the volume ramp expected over the year. Net debt £590m up from £560m with ND/EBITDA 2.6x on LTM adjusted EBITDA basis.
● Guidance unchanged. Q1 inevitably means a significant weighting to H2 and the seasonally strong Q4. Normal seasonal pattern will be assisted by launch of the DBS Superleggera Volante in Q3, Vantage AMR in Q4 and delivery of the DB4 GT Zagato Continuation specials, with these specials positive for profitability. D&A will trend upwards but marketing spend is expected to reduce due to fewer launches suggesting overall SG&A/D&A to be broadly flat through the year.

JP11:35am

Trading update –delivering strong growth Although market conditions have been more volatile, Hargreaves has delivered another strong period of growth. Flows were slightly better than expected and overall AUA grew by 14%. With the stock trading materially ahead of our target price, we place it under review until we re-assess the long-term potential and what this means for short-term valuation metrics.

Pharma Ah, JP listens to Miles Davis, and is correspondingly mellow and chilled.Any suggestions from the ROTR on what BE listens to to get in his inimitable Markets Live mood?
JP11:35am

Positive inflows. Today’s statement from Hargreaves covers the four month period to 30 April. Overall, the business has generated good net inflows in the period, despite what were more challenging conditions. In the four month period net inflows were £2.9bn, slightly behind last year’s £3.3bn when market conditions were more positive but ahead of consensus expectations of £2.8bn. There was also a benefit from recovering markets from the lows at December, with total AuA at the end of April rising to £97.8bn after £9.0bn of positive market movements. The overall growth was driven by a number of different factors: new clients, ongoing wealth consolidation from existing clients, £339m into Active Savings and a back book transfer of £267m (with further transfers likely to benefit FY20).

JP11:37am

And here's Shore Capital Markets:

JP11:37am

In a scheduled ten-month trading update (the company traditionally chooses the end of April rather than March to capture the influence of the new tax year), HL has reported Assets under Administration (AuA) of £97.8bn at 30th April (company-compiled consensus £95.1bn). This represents an increase of whopping £11.9bn (13.9%) since the last reported figure of £85.6bn at 31st December. This increase splits down as net inflows of £2.9bn (consensus £2.8bn) and positive market movements of £9.0bn (10.5% of 31st Dec AuA).

Our last published forecasts were issued on 30th January after the interim results in a note entitled Ouch! Markets bite back. HL had seen AuA drop by £8.5bn (9%) in the final (calendar) quarter of 2018 (excluding Active Savings). While net inflows had contributed £0.9bn in that quarter, the negative market movement figure was a surprisingly large £9.4bn. At that point we downgraded our Jun ’19 full year market movement assumption to -£5.5bn (-6%) and full year net inflow assumption to £5.5bn to arrive at a closing figure of £91.6bn. We expected to make a positive mark-to-market following today’s update but the upgrades will be greater than we anticipated and we would now expect HL to finish the year at c£100bn AuA.

Net revenue for the ten months is disclosed as £395.9m (company-compiled consensus £396m), implying £159.5m for the four months since 31st Dec. This leaves HL needing £85.3m in the final two months of the year to meet current Bloomberg consensus revenue of £481m, a figure which we would expect to see upgraded to c£490-495m.

11:37 am
JP11:37am

As ever, we were keen to see the progress at HL’s innovative cash savings service, Active Savings. Balances increased from £385m at 31st December to £784m at 30th April, a run-rate of c£100m per month. Note that HL only introduced the first instant-access product at the end of January. While we estimate the revenue yield on Active Savings is still well below the planned 25bps, we are hugely encouraged by today’s figures and see it as a major source of future valuation creation (representing £2bn or 290p/share in our last published fair value)

At last night’s closing price of 2307p and before we implement a positive mark-to-market upgrade (provisionally c4-5% to Jun ’19 and closer to 8-9% for Jun ’20 and ‘21) HL trades on 44x our last published Jun ’19 eps of 51.9p (PBT £305.7m), falling to 42x in Jun ’20 (PBT £322.7m, eps 55.1p) and a prospective Jun ’19 dividend yield of 1.8% (42.0p , including a 8.3p special).

We regard Hargreaves Lansdown as the bluest of blue chips. Its business model is a thing of beauty to which Active Savings is the cherry on the top. The only issue we usually have to consider is the extent to which the future growth prospects are adequately captured in the prevailing share price. Our inclination is that following a strong run, predictably fuelled by the market rally since 31st December, the current price is up with events. We expect to upgrade our last published fair value (1780p) to c2000p on the back of the higher reported AuA but would not commit new money at current levels. HOLD

JP11:42am

So @red has been asking for something, anything on Bayer. So here's UBS's take:

JP11:42am

Another large jury award in California
Overnight the jury in the Pilliod case (plaintiff couple) awarded $55m in compensation damages and $2bn in punitive damages against Bayer for both plaintiffs combined. The jury found that Roundup had been defectively designed, that the company failed to warn of the herbicide's cancer risk and that the company acted negligently. This is the third jury case Bayer has lost with $80m ($5m compensation/$75m in punitive damages) awarded in the Hardeman case and $289m awarded in the Johnson case ($39m compensation/$250m punitive) which was reduced to $76m in post trial motion. The next trial is scheduled in Missouri in August.

11:42 am
JP11:42am

Jury punitive damage awards have been revised down in the past
Whilst the punitive damage awards are big, historic cases suggest they tend to come down in post-trial motions and the Supreme Court ruled in 2003 that 'excessive damages' are unconstitutional. For instance as discussed here the judge in the Johnson case reduced compensation damages in post-trial motion. Overall the full appeal ruling is not likely until the end of the year. Whether the jury verdict will ultimately stand in the Hardeman case is still unknown. We note that currently the Pilliod case compensation award (for two plaintiffs) sits between the two prior cases.

red tks
JP11:42am

Settlement still the most likely scenario
As we have previously written (here) product liability litigations in pharma tend to end up in settlements. However, at this point it is impossible to estimate the average pay-out per potential case and any potential settlement is likely a topic for 2020, not this year. Large litigations in pharma have settled in the low to mid-single digit billion range even where the number of plaintiffs was in the thousands. We include a mid-single digit billion settlement of our downside scenario (approximately €5 per share) but pending further clarification, our base case remains unchanged with no litigation settlement.
Valuation:
We value Bayer on a DCF basis (WACC 6%, 2% terminal growth, ROIC fading back to WACC medium term). This yields our price target of €110.

JP11:43am

Extremely punchy price target: €110 is 95 per cent odd higher than where the shares trade at the moment.

Via the FT:

JP11:49am

British Land swung to a loss in the year to March as turmoil in the retail sector dragged down the value of one of the UK’s largest listed property portfolios. 

The FTSE 100 group on Wednesday reported a loss of £319m for the year, down from a £501m profit a year earlier as retailers’ battle for survival fed through into property prices.

A 4.8 per cent drop in the value of British Land’s properties to £12.3bn was led by an 11.1 per cent slide in the value of its retail assets, which include Sheffield’s Meadowhall centre. 

JP11:50am

Anyway, market seems to have priced most of it in.

11:51 am
JP11:51am

Here's Peel Hunt:

Pharma @red, everything is always in the price - eventually.
Phil Since we’re talking about them: Question for the assembled rabble: Is HL still the most reasonable SIPP provider? (Assuming no complex requirements like sticking a rental property in a SIPP etc)
JP11:51am

Prelims: retail woes offset growth in London BL’s FY19 total accounting return of -3.3% reflects the anticipated weakness of retail assets (c45% of portfolio), which fell in value by 11.1% over the year, and a good showing from the £6.3bn office portfolio where rents continue to grow. A proposed 3% increase in the FY20 dividend is consistent with previous years, and helps to provide some support to the income story here but, like Landsec, it is only as a result of the large NAV discount.

JP11:52am

Financials EPRA NAV fell 6.4% to 905p which is 2% behind our forecast and consensus and is a larger fall than the 4.1% reported by Landsec yesterday. Underlying EPS down 6.7% to 34.9p which is marginally ahead of our forecast (34p) and consensus. The decline is down to a one off surrender premium in last year’s comparable. Full year dividend was up 3.0% to 31p in line with guidance. •A proposed dividend increase for FY20 of 3%. Total accounting return for FY19 of -3.3% compares to Landsec at -1.2%. LTV of 28.1%, and a further share buyback of up to £125m announced.

11:52 am
JP11:52am

Portfolio The portfolio fell by 4.8% driven largely driven by retail which was down 11.1%. Offices were up 1.1% and developments were up 10.8%. The valuation movements are marginally ahead of what Landsec reported yesterday although BL’s heavier weighting to shopping centres and retail parks has led to its underperformance. ERVs were down 3.8% across the retail portfolio most notably in retail parks which were down 4.6%. The annualised rent impact from CVAs and administrations over the past two years is now £16.9m, with 61 units subject to closure. 42 have been re-let or are in negotiation. Canada Water fell in value by 0.8% to £303m, with an uplift in value offset by costs incurred. The first detailed planning application was submitted in May. As previously disclosed, BL see a business mix in five year’s time of 55-60% London offices, 30-35% retail, and c10% residential.

Bluesky21 @Phil. I think HL is fine for funds; questionable for stocks, especially non-UK stocks.
JP11:52am

Forecasts & valuation We reduce our FY20 NAV forecast by 2% to c875p to reflect today’s lower NAV but we expect to keep our EPS and DPS forecasts unchanged at 35.5p and 31.9p respectively. The shares trade on a 36% discount to our FY20 NAV and a 5.7% dividend yield.

Excel Developer @red: do you actually believe in efficient market hypothesis?
nightingale20201 @bluesky21..ditto your comments

Worth noting that a lot of local councils are using commercial assets to fund themselves.

JP11:54am

Panmure are pretty non-plussed about the results, here's analyst Miranda Cockburn's take:

red gbpdem what a pair that used to be
Shinshin @phil reverse opinion to others above, HL sipp better for stocks bec fee capped but is higher for funds. Service and security are excellent, you need to do a price model vs others for your size of fund and trdaaing frequency because that's what makes the cost differences stand out
11:55 am
JP11:55am

Results in line with expectations with similar underlying sub-sector performances to Landsec yesterday and a similar move to focus on mixed-use rather than the individual sub-sectors. The two key differences are firstly that British Land has continued to develop over the past few years in London whereas Landsec shut up shop [and is only just starting again] and secondly that British Land’s shopping centre/retail park exposure accounts for 38% of its total portfolio versus 26% for Landsec. We think this second point has been the driver of the relative outperformance of Landsec over British Land year to date [and resulted in British Land’s discount to NAV rising to 38% from 30% a year ago] but given the weak outlook we retain our Hold rating.

Excel Developer @red: I am sceptical. I worked at Chemical Bank (later subsumed in JP Morgan) FX trading room circa 1990. It could go nuts when a macro surprise happened.
JP11:56am

And to round it up, UBS:

Pharma Ten years ago council finance officers put all their cash into Icesave accounts.Now they are investing in retail and commercial property.Have we discovered the perfect sell signal?
JP11:56am

More space let than in any of the last five years
British Land's results were slightly below on NAV but slightly ahead on EPS, as its retail exposure continued to bite, while leasing levels were good across the portfolio. NAV fell 6.4% (Landsec: -4.6%) to 905p (Consensus 920p; UBSe 930p), as the portfolio dropped 4.8%, entirely due to the 11% fall in retail. We still have a further 17% decline for multi-let retail in our numbers, so to some extent this is a timing issue. More encouragingly, British Land let 2.7m sq ft in total, ahead of ERV; more space than in any of the last five years, and this takes the developments to 76% pre-let. LTV remains comfortable at 28%, as disposals continue: British Land has sold £646m of retail 2% ahead of book value, which is impressive in this market, and it sticks by its aim to reduce retail to one-third of the portfolio (from c.45% currently).

11:56 am
JP11:56am

Portfolio down 4.8%: Retail down 11.1% and Offices up 1.1%
The portfolio fell 4.8%, worse than Landsec (-4.1%), reflecting higher exposure to the more troubled retail sub-sectors. Offices gained 1.1% driven by office developments, where continued leasing activities delivered an uplift of 11.3%; retail fell 11.1% as a combined result of falling ERVs due to CVAs and 37bps yield outshift. By submarket, Department Stores fared the worst, down 40% (due to Debenhams exposure), albeit on a small base (£70m). Shopping Parks fell 13.2% and Shopping Centres were down 9.8%. The topped up initial yield now stands at 4.8%. EPS dropped 6.7% to 34.9p (UBSe: 34.0p) due to the one-off lease surrender last year and disposal impact.

JP11:56am

Leasing ahead of ERV, retail metrics fall but outperform
Leasing levels were high with office lettings covering 1.1m sq ft, or £21m, slightly behind FY18 (1.2m sq ft), signed 1.2% ahead of ERV. However, an additional 28,000 sq ft is under offer and another 479,000 sq ft is in negotiations. Retail lettings of 1.6m sq ft were made 0.3% ahead of ERV (the value of retail ERVs in a CVA world is a different debate). Retail remains tough, however: footfall was down 90bps, outperforming its benchmark by 230bps; and retailer sales fell 0.5%, outperforming the benchmark by 160bps.
Valuation: trades at a 39% disc. to spot NAV (vs. 23% disc. for UK).
Our PT is economic profit-based, and equates to a 14% discount to NAV.

JP11:58am

Just seen this on FastFt:

11:58 am
JP11:58am

German criminal prosecutors, police and tax investigators this morning began raiding eleven German lenders looking for evidence of suspected tax fraud by clients of a former Deutsche Bank offshore unit.

The raids are taking place in Frankfurt and six other cities across Germany and involve officers from the Federal Criminal Police, the Hamburg State Office of Criminal investigation and six different regional tax authorities.

Eight individuals who were clients of a British Virgin Islands-based former Deutsche Bank unit are in the crosshairs of the investigators.

A person familiar with the investigation told the Financial Times that to this best knowledge, none of those suspects are Deutsche Bank employees.

JP12:05pm

Campling:

12:05 pm
JP12:05pm

Normally we get a lot of detail on the net other gains...we don't this quarter. It looks to us like it is mainly non-GAAP adjustments including marking to market valuations on investee companies. So, no it isn't a clean compare in that headline (Q1 net income Y27.2B versus consensus Y19.4B) which drove Naspers up +4% (although now currently -1.5%). Group revenues missed consensus by nearly 4%, due to being 10% light on advertising side. It appears this is a combination of weaker seasonality on ad spending, macro uncertainty and delay in airing top-drama on video platform (this will be the government approval issue on drama that affected the industry in Q1 – one referenced by Tencent earlier this year but perhaps not taken fully into account by consensus).

For the first time the company break out FinTech and Business Services (aka Cloud). Revenues for this segment grew 44% YoY, although the cost of those revenues grew faster, at 72%. So this gives a margin of 29%, half the valuation of VAS (which is driven by gaming) which has a margin of 58%. You’d assume that higher cost would be the cloud/data-centre build out but hopefully that will become clearer on the conference call.

red @Bluesky21yes id agree with the comments. its another how long is a piece of string argument, when measuring liability. its going to hang until they take a charge. at some point between the charge and the settle, it will bottom.
JP12:05pm

Now the good news is that gaming #s are good versus consensus and that's the key. Online gaming Y28.5B, -1% YoY with smartphone games -2% YoY but +11% QoQ as we now have the game approval freeze in the rear view mirror. New Game perfect world mobile was launched late in Q1 so this helps game cash receipts (+10% YoY) but this gets reflected in revenue recognition next quarter. Q2 looks set up strongly for gaming. You have PUBG MOBILE now exceeding 100M MAUs since February, early introduction of Season passes in key games in China including Honour of Kings and Cross Fire Mobile in April, and just launched the intro of season passes internationally for Fortnite and PUBG. These help user engagement, paying ratio and revenue generation. Now gaming for Q2 2018 fell -13% QoQ, whereas we would expect it to grow double digit QoQ this year. Tencent is more the liquid equity emerging market proxy than anything else at the moment, driven as much by Trump tweets as much as fundamentals. But when the world decides to return to the micro then Tencent looking ahead for the balance of 2019 faces easy comparisons, the return to growth of gaming, has a big release slate of titles and the monetisation model of season passes that has proved phenomenally successful for digital games such as Fortnite. BUY
